Points in "general" position


Draft
Posted on June 18, 2025 by Yu Cong
Tags: combinatorics, CG

1 General Position

An set of 2D points is said to be in general position if any 3 points are not collinear. Given a set of points P in the plane, find the largest subset S⊂P in general position.

1.1 Related Problems/Works

  • A recent paper [1] studied the “typical size” of the largest point set in general position in which each points is taken from Fq3​ iid with probability p. “Typical size” means we want upper and lower bounds with high probability. Piror to this work, [2] gave an upperbound for the case of Fq2​. A set of points S⊂Fqd​ is in general position if there are no d+1 points in S contained in a (d−1)-dimensional affine subspace. [1] also mentioned some non-random bounds. The max size of a point set in general position in Fqd​ is at least q and at most (1+o(1))q.
  • [3] studied the problem of finding the largest subset of points in general position in a point set P⊂Q2. They showed that this problem is NP-hard, APX-hard and no 2o(n)nO(1)-time alg under ETH. The reduction is from graph independent set.
  • This blog post discusses constructions of general-position point sets ⊂Z2 with some extremal structures.
  • [4] improved the upperbound of the max number a(d,k,n) of points selected from [n]d such that no k+2 members lie on a k-flat.

2 Integer Program and Duality

Let P be a set of n points in the plane. We can define (2n​) lines and write a point-line incidence matrix A(2n​)×n​ which indicates if point p is on the line defined by {p1​,p2​}. Now we can write an IP for finding the largest subset of P in general position.

maxs.t.​​p∑​p∑​​xp​Ai,p​xp​≤2xp​∈{0,1}​​∀i∈[(2n​)]​​

Consider its LP dual,

mins.t.​​i∑​i∑​​2yi​Ai,p​yi​≥1yi​∈{0,1}​​∀p∈P​​

One can see that the dual is finding the smallest number of lines to cover points in P. Denote by σ the max number of general position points in P and let α be the minimum line covering number. (Borrow these symbols from matroid strength and density.) There are some results in [3].

Observation1

α​<σ≤2α.

Proof

The second inequality directly follows from LP duality. For the first inequality, note that the largest set of points in general position defines (2σ​) lines and any other point must lie on one of these lines. Thus these (2σ​) lines cover every points in P. We have α≤(2σ​)<σ2.

2.1 Approximation

Now I am interested in the gaps of above IPs and approximations algorithms for σ. For the n×n grid case there is a 3/4 approximation [5]. It seems that in general cases the currently best known polynomial time approximation ratio is σ​ ? (see Cheng Cao’s master thesis and chatper 9.5 of David Eppstein’s book) One can easily prove that the simple greedy method gives a σ​ approximation.

3 Open Problems

  1. No Three in Line problem: find the max number of points that can be placed in the n×n grid such that there is no collinear triple. An easy upperbound is 2n. The currently best lowerbound is 23​n−o(n) [5]. The main interest here is to get better bounds.
